texts.text-8-3: Some information about the spectacled caiman...
texts.text-8-4: It is a type of crocodile from the Alligatoridae family.
texts.text-8-5: Its common name is broad-snouted caiman and its scientific name, Caiman latirostris.
texts.text-8-6: It can exceed three meters in length.
texts.text-8-7: It builds its nest in some tranquil lagoon.
texts.text-8-8: To do this, form a mound with materials found at the place.
texts.text-8-9: The nest can be up to 1 meter in diameter and 60 centimeters in height.
texts.text-8-10: The females take care of the young on their own, protecting them from potential predators such as birds of prey.
texts.text-8-11: Its diet is exclusively carnivorous; it primarily consumes snails and other mollusks and crustaceans.
texts.text-8-12: It captures reptiles and small mammals, such as rats, mice, and bats.
texts.text-8-13: Their main natural enemies are the caracara, the crab hawk, and the wild boar.
texts.text-8-14: But above all, human beings who want to hunt it to make wallets and shoes with its skin.
texts.text-8-15: It inhabits swampy and lacustrine regions of Bolivia, Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay, and Uruguay.
texts.text-8-16: In Uruguay, it can be found on the basin of the Merín Lagoon, from Rocha to Cerro Largo, in the northern part of the Negro River, in the Tacuarembó River, and along the coast up to Paysandú.
texts.text-8-17: They call it overo because its skin has a coloration of diffuse spots, between intense green and pale gray.
texts.text-8-18: Thanks to the color of its skin, it can blend in with the dense vegetation of its habitat.
texts.text-9-0: Many things are said about me...
texts.text-9-1: Some Indigenous peoples of America believe that my teeth have healing powers.
texts.text-9-2: Supposedly, if they hang from the neck or an arm, they avoid snake bites, and if they don't avoid them, the venom becomes harmless.
texts.text-9-4: They also believe that pressing and scraping one of my teeth over the snake bite and sucking it is a foolproof remedy.
texts.text-9-6: Others say that my teeth are very powerful to defeat the air. How is this?
texts.text-9-7: In folk medicine, it is believed that an air current can penetrate the body and cause muscle pain.
texts.text-9-8: If I move one of my teeth over the painful area, it absorbs the air and relieves the pain.
texts.text-9-9: Others speak of the power that my sharp vertebrae have, that if they are used by warriors to inflict bleeding in different parts of the body, they instill strength and courage in them.
texts.text-9-12: That day the men who sank into the river to avoid burning turned into caimans and capybaras.
texts.text-9-11: The Guarani believe that my origin dates back to a time when the Earth would have collided with the Sun and a great fire occurred.
texts.text-9-13: Find an interesting piece of information about the yacaré. Write it down.

texts.text-12-9: How does the tropical rainforest differ from the desert? And the tundra from the prairie?
texts.text-12-10: And what is the difference between a temperate forest and a tropical forest?
texts.text-12-11: What similarities do the prairie and the savanna have?
texts.text-12-12: Why do some living beings inhabit one region and not another?
texts.text-12-13: Some answers to these questions can be found on pages 14, 15, and 16.
texts.text-13-1: Life on our planet depends on the sun's energy, the availability of water, and the existence of nutrients in the soil, among other factors.
texts.text-13-2: But not all regions of the world have the same conditions.
texts.text-13-3: In each region of the planet, there are different climates, landforms, and types of soil that create the environmental conditions for the development of life in that place.
texts.text-13-4: In each region lives a group of beings adapted to the place they inhabit.
texts.text-13-5: For example, in the desert, both plants and animals are adapted to the low availability of water.
texts.text-13-6: The living beings that inhabit a region also interact with each other, for example, some are food for others.
texts.text-13-7: Each of the regions in which living beings interact with each other and with the place where they live is called an ecosystem.
texts.text-13-8: On Earth, we find similar ecosystems in places that are very distant from each other.
texts.text-13-9: For example, there are jungles or tropical forests in Central Africa, northern South America, and southwestern Asia.
texts.text-13-11: Humans are part of the living beings that inhabit biomes.
texts.text-13-12: To meet their needs, humans modify the natural environment.
texts.text-13-13: For example, they cultivate fields, construct buildings, bridges, highways, among other transformations.
texts.text-13-14: The specialists point out that currently there are no completely natural environments anymore, that is, those that have not been modified by human action.
texts.text-13-15: The transformation of nature is essential for human life, but it is often carried out without the necessary care, resulting in damage that can be irreparable.
texts.text-13-17: Climate and topography play a significant role in the formation of biomes.
texts.text-13-18: For example, some mountain ranges act as large walls blocking the path of humid winds coming from the ocean.
texts.text-13-19: When these winds hit the mountain, they release their moisture on the side facing the sea, while the other side is arid.
texts.text-13-20: Likewise, height is a determining factor: in the mountains, biomes are distributed in layers, according to height.
texts.text-14-0: Excessive deforestation, indiscriminate hunting of some species, intensive fishing (hake, for example), and drilling of land for mining exploitation (oil, coal, and other minerals) are some examples of activities that can cause damage to the planet.
texts.text-14-1: Environmental specialists propose that human activities be developed taking into account the needs of future generations.
texts.text-14-2: This type of development is called sustainable development.
texts.text-14-3: The World Commission on Environment of the United Nations (UN) defines sustainable development as "development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs."
texts.text-14-6: They are also called tropical forests.
texts.text-14-7: They develop in areas of high temperatures and abundant rainfall for much of the year.
texts.text-14-8: They extend to both sides of the equator in Central America, South America, Africa, Asia, and Australia.
texts.text-14-11: They have a large quantity and variety of plants: large, medium, and small trees, lianas, vines, ferns, shrubs, and herbaceous vegetation, distributed in layers (the tallest trees form a canopy under which the other species live in a disorderly and tangled manner).
texts.text-14-12: They also present a large quantity and variety of animals, for example, monkeys, reptiles, birds, insects, and predatory mammals.
texts.text-14-13: Economic activities are linked to the exploitation of forest and mineral resources.
texts.text-14-14: Deforestation or the logging of species causes severe consequences, such as loss of biodiversity, global climate changes, disappearance of animal and plant species, and loss of soils.
texts.text-15-1: They develop in areas with temperate and cold climates.
texts.text-15-2: The trees of the forests are located forming a single layer and very spaced apart, and they have a period of dormancy during the winter.
texts.text-15-3: There is less variety of vegetables and animals than in the jungle.
texts.text-15-4: In temperate zones, the forests consist of deciduous trees and shrubs, while those in colder regions are made up of conifers, trees with evergreen foliage.
texts.text-15-5: The fauna of the forests is mainly made up of predators, such as foxes, wolves, pumas, and lynxes.
texts.text-15-6: In temperate forests, land clearing for timber or for the development of agriculture and livestock farming leads to the loss of animal and plant species.
texts.text-15-7: The taiga is a forest characteristic of the cold climates of the northern hemisphere; it develops in Canada and Siberia.
texts.text-15-8: The characteristic species are firs, pines, larches, and birches.
texts.text-15-9: Its fauna consists of animals that withstand the cold: moose, bison, wolves, bears, lynxes, squirrels, marmots, beavers, and deer; many of them hibernate.
texts.text-15-11: They develop in areas with a temperate and humid climate.
texts.text-15-12: They lack trees almost entirely and have a large amount of tender, even grass.
texts.text-15-13: They are ideal for the development of agricultural activities, such as cereal and oilseed cultivation, and livestock activities, for example, cattle breeding.

texts.text-26-1: The Kenyan biologist Wangari Maathai wanted to combat the poverty that deforestation was generating in her country.
texts.text-26-2: To do so, he started planting trees and invited others to imitate the initiative.
texts.text-26-3: Thus, with its Green Belt project, it promoted the planting of more than 47 million trees in Africa.
texts.text-26-4: In 2004, he/she received the Nobel Peace Prize for his/her defense of sustainable development and the environment.
texts.text-26-6: Chico Mendes was a rubber tapper who peacefully fought for the preservation of the Brazilian rainforest.
texts.text-26-7: He reported the damage of indiscriminate logging and managed to mobilize many people who joined his cause.
texts.text-26-8: The landowners harmed by his struggle killed him, but he raised environmental awareness in Brazil, America, and the whole world.
texts.text-26-10: Jacques-Yves Cousteau was a French explorer who traveled the world researching marine biomes.
texts.text-26-11: He filmed underwater documentaries and spread knowledge about the different forms of life that inhabit the sea.
texts.text-26-12: He organized campaigns to stop the dumping of radioactive waste into the sea and, with the support of many people, succeeded more than once.
texts.text-26-14: The Inuit, inhabitants of the Arctic, know the magnificent biodiversity of the area they inhabit and are direct witnesses to the environmental damage in the region.
texts.text-26-15: Caroline Cannon, a member of this community, has faced powerful companies interested in the oil wealth of the Arctic region for years.
texts.text-26-16: Work alongside groups of scientists to halt the destruction of the environment where they live.

texts.text-31-6: Forests provide a habitat for a wide variety of plants and animals and perform many other functions that affect humans.
texts.text-31-7: Together with others, these large plant communities are responsible, for example, for the production of oxygen during photosynthesis.
texts.text-31-8: Photosynthesis is the chemical process by which green leaves and stems use sunlight and carbon dioxide to produce sugars that provide energy to the tree.
texts.text-31-9: During the process, the foliage of the trees releases oxygen, an element necessary for respiration.
texts.text-31-10: Forests also prevent erosion, that is, the wear of the soil caused by wind and rain.
texts.text-31-11: In bare areas, with little or no vegetation, rain can wash soil into rivers and streams, causing landslides and floods.
texts.text-31-12: However, in densely wooded areas, the roots of trees and plants hold the soil and slow down these processes.
texts.text-31-13: In forested areas, the leaf canopy (the tree tops) gradually intercepts and redistributes rainwater.
texts.text-31-14: A portion of the precipitation then flows down the bark of the trunks and the rest runs through the branches and foliage.
texts.text-31-15: That slower and more uneven distribution of rain contributes to the soil not being washed away immediately.
texts.text-31-16: In this way, the possibility of flooding and erosion is reduced.
texts.text-31-17: Forests can also increase the earth's capacity to retain and store water reserves.
texts.text-31-18: The canopy of leaves is particularly efficient at capturing water from fog (condensed water vapor).
texts.text-31-19: The water captured in the tree canopies is then distributed to the vegetation and the soil as precipitation.
texts.text-31-20: The water stored in the roots, trunks, stems, foliage, and soil of the forest land allows forests to maintain a constant flow of moisture during times of drought.

texts.text-35-1: Write a list with the environmental problems that the inhabitants of large cities must face daily.
texts.text-35-4: Complete the previous activity with the new information provided by the article.
texts.text-35-6: Large cities often have various problems arising from managing a limited area where millions of people live.
texts.text-35-7: Air pollution is a serious problem in some cities.
texts.text-35-8: It is caused by the emission of gases from vehicle traffic and industries.
texts.text-35-9: Smog is the haze that remains in the city, which causes health problems and creates an urban microclimate characterized by an increase in temperature.
texts.text-35-10: Heavy traffic is also a source of noise pollution.
texts.text-35-11: The permanent movement of the population within the city and between it and neighboring cities creates transportation problems.
texts.text-35-12: Many times transportation systems are not sufficient, which causes congestion and chaos during peak hours.
texts.text-35-13: A large city consumes significant volumes of water, food, and energy.
texts.text-35-14: Similarly, economic activities and households generate thousands of tons of garbage every day, which the city's public services must collect, treat, and deposit in final disposal sites.
texts.text-35-15: The same happens with wastewater, which must be channeled through sanitation systems, which do not always exist or are not sufficient.

texts.text-39-1: Many centuries ago, travelers and explorers wrote descriptions of nature, although they were not as precise as those of current science.
texts.text-39-2: After an exploratory trip through the Caribbean, Melchor de Barros claimed to have seen a region with such fertile land that giant trees grew there.
texts.text-39-3: They were so large that it was impossible to reach their tops by shooting arrows, and it took six men holding hands to encircle their gigantic trunks.
texts.text-39-5: This is how the English navigator Walter Raleigh described the inhabitants of America: men who have their heads lower than their shoulders, others with feet so large they use them as sunshades, some with three rows of teeth in each jaw, bodies like bears, legs like lions, and scorpions' tails.
texts.text-39-7: Christopher Columbus, in the diary of his first voyage to America in 1492, described the American landscape as follows: "The sea as calm as a river and the finest airs in the world... The singing of the little birds is such that it seems one would never want to leave here, and the flocks of parrots darken the sun."
texts.text-39-9: Which of these travelers can we believe?

texts.sectioneli5-0-0: This is a fun book for fifth-grade children to practice reading and writing. It features a friendly crocodile that accompanies you in learning. The book is made by educational institutions to help students improve their academic skills.
texts.sectioneli5-2-0: This is a special notebook that helps fifth-grade children learn to read and write better. It is part of their education in primary school so they can practice and improve their skills with words.
texts.sectioneli5-6-0: The index is like a list of what is in the book. It tells you what topics and stories you can find and on what page they are. For example, you can read about 'I am Yacaré' or discover stories about 'Antiprincesses' that break the rules of fairy tales. It's like a map of the book so that you can find everything easily and quickly.
texts.sectioneli5-7-0: Hello! I am Yacaré. I will be with you while you read and write. Think of me as a friend who accompanies you while we do fun reading and writing activities together.
texts.sectioneli5-7-1: When you see the crocodile Yacaré with a pencil, he is inviting you to write. It's as if he's saying: "Let's write together." So grab your pencil and start writing with him.
texts.sectioneli5-7-2: When you see this friendly crocodile with a book, it means he is inviting you to read with him. It's his fun way of saying: 'Come, let's enjoy reading together!'.
texts.sectioneli5-7-3: When you see Yacaré forming a circle with friends, it's time to listen to a story. He invites you to pay attention and enjoy the reading together. This means it's time to be calm and listen attentively.
texts.sectioneli5-8-0: Here we have some special friends: a jaguar wearing shorts, an owl with a red shirt, and a caiman hiding secrets in the fourth book. These fun characters invite us to learn together and tell us they will see us in the sixth course for more adventures. They are here to make learning more entertaining and exciting.
texts.sectioneli5-8-1:
The yacaré overo is a large crocodile that lives in places with a lot of water in countries like Bolivia and Brazil. It is like a large reptile that measures more than three meters.

Its skin has spots that help it hide in the green plants of its home. Additionally, it builds its nest with things it finds to protect the baby yacarés from animals that want to eat them, like some birds.

It likes to eat snails and small animals like rats. However, humans are also a danger because they sometimes hunt it to use its skin. It likes to live near lakes and rivers, where it feels more comfortable. That is the yacaré overo, a very special crocodile.
texts.sectioneli5-9-0: Some people in America believe that the teeth you see in the image have magical powers. It is said that if you wear them around your neck or arm, they can protect you from snake bites or make the venom harmless.
texts.sectioneli5-9-1: Some people believe that if a snake bites you, you can use a special tooth to scrape the bite area while sucking a little. It is thought that this may help as a magical remedy to cure the poison. It's like an old story about how people used to treat these situations.
texts.sectioneli5-9-2: In some places, people believe that using a special tooth can help relieve muscle pain. They think that this tooth can "absorb the bad air" from the body, making you feel better. The image shows a person using a tooth on another person's back to help with their pain.
texts.sectioneli5-9-3: Some people believe that sharp vertebrae have a special power. They say that if warriors use them to make small cuts on themselves, they feel that it gives them strength and courage, as if they were superheroes.
texts.sectioneli5-9-4: According to a Guarani story, a long time ago, something incredible happened: the Earth collided with the Sun and everything caught fire. The men, to avoid being burned, went into the river. Upon entering the water, they transformed into caimans and capybaras! It is a story that magically explains where these animals come from.
texts.sectioneli5-9-5: The text asks you to find something curious about the yacaré and either write or draw it. The images show that several stories describe that the teeth or bones of the yacaré have special powers according to the beliefs of some cultures. So you can research and share one of those interesting facts yourself.
texts.sectioneli5-10-0: Here we do an exercise to talk about a special friend. Think of a friend and write things about him or her. For example, what is his or her name, how do their friends call them, what color is their hair and eyes, what things they like a lot, what things they don't like, who they like to play with, and what makes them happy or sad. Thus, we put all that information together to better know that friend. It's like making a little map about your special friend!
texts.sectioneli5-10-1: Use this sheet to draw or put a photo of your friend. Then, fill in the spaces with information about him or her, such as their name, what they like to play, their hair and eye color, and what makes them happy or sad. After that, write a short paragraph describing your friend using that information. This way, you can share what your best friend is like.
texts.sectioneli5-12-0:
On Earth, there are different places that have special plants and animals. Some of these places are:

- **Rainforest:** Full of trees and plants.
- **Prairie:** Large green fields without many trees.
- **Temperate Forest:** Trees with leaves that change with the seasons.
- **Desert:** Very dry with sand.
- **Steppe:** Flat and dry land, with few trees.
- **Tundra:** Very cold and icy.
- **Taiga:** Cold forests with large trees.

Each place is special, and maps show where they are in the world.
texts.sectioneli5-12-1: The questions are about different places on Earth. A tropical rainforest has many trees, is hot, and rains a lot. A desert is very dry and hot with few plants. The tundra is cold and has little vegetation, while the prairie has many grasses and some flowers. A temperate forest has seasons with cold and heat, and a tropical forest is always hot and rainy. Each is different because of its climate, plants, and animals.
texts.sectioneli5-12-2: The prairies and savannas are similar because both are large expanses filled with grass and few trees. Animals and plants live in specific places because they need certain things to survive, like climate or food. Therefore, some animals live in the savanna and others in the tundra, depending on what they need to be happy and safe.
texts.sectioneli5-13-0: On our planet, there are different types of places called biomes. These are places like forests, deserts, or jungles. Each biome has a different climate, water, and soil with different nutrients. For example, in the desert there is not much water, so the plants and animals that live there are adapted and do not need much. Each group of plants and animals that lives in a place forms an ecosystem. These ecosystems can be very far apart, but they can be similar, like the jungles in Africa, South America, and Asia. The images show examples of different biomes and how they look.
texts.sectioneli5-13-1: Humans live in biomes, which are natural places like forests and deserts. To live and do things like produce food and build houses, people change nature. They do things like plant fruits, build bridges and roads. It's important to make these changes carefully so that nature is not damaged too much, because sometimes we make changes that we cannot fix.
texts.sectioneli5-13-2: Biomes are large natural areas like forests or deserts. The climate and terrain make these biomes different. For example, mountains can divide winds: one side can be wet and the other dry. Also, the height of the mountains changes how the biomes are, forming different layers of plants and animals at different levels.
texts.sectioneli5-14-0: When we cut down many trees, hunt too many animals, or extract many things from the earth to obtain resources like oil, we are harming the planet. Therefore, experts say that we should do these things in a way that does not harm our home or the future of the next generations. This is called "sustainable development," which means using what we need now, but ensuring that our grandchildren also have what they need.
texts.sectioneli5-14-1:
The jungles, or tropical rainforests, are places where it is very hot and it rains a lot throughout the year. You can find them in South America, Central America, Africa, Asia, and Australia. The Amazon is the largest rainforest, it is truly enormous and extends over 7,000,000 square kilometers!

In the rainforests, there are many types of plants and animals. There are very tall trees that form a canopy, and underneath there are vines, shrubs, and much more. Monkeys, birds, insects, and many other animals live in the rainforests.

When people cut down trees to use the wood or search for minerals, many different plants and animals can be lost. This is called deforestation and it's bad for our planet because it causes animals to disappear, affects the climate, and damages the soil.
texts.sectioneli5-15-0:
Forests are places with many trees, mainly in climates where it is cold or there are temperate seasons, like in the image of green trees with mountains. In these forests, the trees are quite spaced apart and seem to take a break in winter. Here, it is harder to find different types of plants and animals than in the jungle. 

There are two types of trees in forests: those that lose their leaves and others that are always green, called conifers. The animals that live here are usually hunters, like foxes and wolves. In very cold forests, such as the taiga in Canada and Siberia, animals that withstand the cold, such as bears and lynxes, live here, and some even sleep all winter!
texts.sectioneli5-15-1: The prairies are large fields of green grass that have almost no trees. They are cool and humid places, perfect for planting things like grains and for raising animals like cows. The image shows a prairie in Uruguay, where everything looks very green and open.
texts.sectioneli5-16-0: In this activity, we are learning how to identify the main theme of a text. Think of titles as the names of the parts of the book you just read about ‘The Biomes’. You need to see what words are repeated a lot, that tells you what it’s all about. And if you see the funny crocodile with the pencil, he's here to help you! For example, when you see subtitles like 'Jungles', that’s a clue for the theme.
texts.sectioneli5-16-1: Here you have to look at the title and subtitles of a text to discover what it is about. The word you see the most in the title and subtitles tells you what the main topic is. So, in the end, you can say what the text is about in a simple sentence.
texts.sectioneli5-16-2: Biomes are like different neighborhoods in nature, and the climate and mountains are very important for knowing what they look like. Imagine that the wind carries water from the ocean and makes rain on one side of the mountain, but the other side remains dry. Moreover, when we go up a mountain, the biomes change as if they were floors of a building, and that makes it special! The funny crocodile can help us remember that learning about nature is fun.
texts.sectioneli5-16-3: This exercise teaches how to find what a text is about. Look for a sentence that summarizes the whole text and write it down. Normally, explanatory texts start with a sentence that states what will be discussed. That sentence is like a summary of the main topic.
texts.sectioneli5-17-0: The resources at school help us study better. For example, the notebook 'My Notes' is where we write important things that we need to remember. The blue folder can be used to store papers and loose sheets. The 'Dictionary' helps us know what words mean and how they are spelled. The small computer is for searching for information on the internet and learning faster. Finally, the 'Science' book teaches us about plants, animals, and the world around us. Everything is organized into groups like science and mathematics so that we can easily find what we need.
texts.sectioneli5-17-1:
Imagine that you are in a library and you need to find books on different topics.

You have a bookshelf with sections such as language, social sciences, natural sciences, mathematics, and art. 
- 'Digital Image' goes in Visual Arts.
- 'Homonyms' goes in Language and Literature.
- 'Rivers of Uruguay' goes in Social Sciences.
- 'Biomes' and 'The Digestive System' go in Natural Sciences.
- 'Types of Polygons' goes in Mathematics.
- 'The Eastern Revolution' and 'Myths and Legends' go in Social Sciences.

This way, you can find the right book more easily when studying.
texts.sectioneli5-17-2:
Let's classify subjects into two types: natural sciences and social sciences. 

- Natural sciences: Here we study nature and how the world works. This includes things like **chemistry** (test tubes), **astronomy** (the telescope), **biology** (DNA), **physics** (E=mc²), and **geology** (rocks).

- Social sciences: Here we learn about people and their societies. This includes **geography** (the globe) and **history** (the book with an hourglass).

In this way, we can see how to group different studies to understand more about the world and people.
texts.sectioneli5-18-0: In this activity, we are shown two images about nature. The first image has arrows showing how air and climate affect a mountain, with rain on one side and dry air on the other. The second image shows a landscape with a mountain and parts like the summit and the valley. We must think about the relationship between these things, such as why it rains more on one side of the mountain and not on the other.
texts.sectioneli5-18-1: Look at the images and think about which side is wetter and which is drier. The 'wet slope' is where there is a lot of rain and the trees look green and fresh. The 'arid slope' is where it doesn't rain much and there are desert plants, like cacti. Try to decide where each would go.
texts.sectioneli5-18-2: Here, you have to look at two images and say why you like one of them more. Do you see something interesting or important in one that is not in the other? Write down why you chose one image and why you did not choose the other. This helps practice how to explain your ideas and decisions.
texts.sectioneli5-19-0: Let's see what questions we can answer after reading about 'The Biomes'. Think of questions like: where are jungles? or what types of biomes are there in Uruguay? It's a bit like searching for clues in a story to find the right answers. If you don't understand, it's okay to read again. This will help you learn more about nature and the world around us.
texts.sectioneli5-19-1: Think of three questions that you can answer after reading about 'Types of Biomes'. Try to make the questions related to what you have learned. Then, share your questions with your friends in class. This will help you to understand better and learn from what others have also discovered.
texts.sectioneli5-19-2: This exercise teaches us to work with our friends. You have to write two questions that your friends have asked and then write the answers. The idea is to practice and better understand what we are learning. Sometimes, it is good to reread something to find the correct answer.
texts.sectioneli5-20-0: We are learning about biomes, which are places in nature like jungles, forests, and prairies. Each has its climate, plants, animals, and activities that people can do there. In the task, you need to read and write the information about each biome in a chart. For example, forests have "temperate climates." Additionally, a small drawing encourages us to complete the chart with the details we find.
texts.sectioneli5-20-1: In this exercise, we have to think about what makes different natural places unique, called biomes. To do this, we are going to use items from a list such as temperature, soil type, whether there are mountains, trees, rain, and more. Imagine that these are pieces of a puzzle that together describe what a place in nature is like. In this way, we learn what makes each biome special, like a forest or a prairie.
texts.sectioneli5-21-0:
The prairies in Uruguay are large fields of grass, like a massive area for cows and horses to graze. The plants that grow there include grasses, shrubs, and legumes, like small plants called chircas.

These prairies cover almost all of Uruguay (80%), which means that many people work in agricultural activities, such as taking care of cows and growing plants, which are very important for the country.

The climate of the prairies is mild, with temperatures around 15 degrees Celsius, and it rains enough, between 500 and 1000 millimeters a year. This makes the plants grow well, like a very large outdoor garden.
texts.sectioneli5-21-1: We are learning about prairies and what they are like. Prairies are places where there is a lot of grass but few trees. They have a temperate and humid climate, which means it is neither too hot nor too cold and it rains quite a bit. These places are perfect for planting things like cereals and raising cows. We need to combine this new information with what we already know to better understand how prairies work.
texts.sectioneli5-21-2: You are going to write a text about the prairies in Uruguay using three pieces of information. Each one tells you something important: one about plants like grasses and shrubs, another about how much agriculture and ranching is done in Uruguay, and another about the climate, which is temperate and humid. You are going to put all that together and check that you use periods and commas well so that the text is nice and complete.
texts.sectioneli5-21-3: In Uruguay, there are fields called prairies. In the prairies, plants such as grasses and shrubs grow. Activities like agriculture and livestock farming are very important because these prairies occupy a lot of space in the country. The climate is mild and humid, being perfect for these important plants to grow. Remember to write a text using this information about the prairies of Uruguay, and make sure to use punctuation correctly! And look, the little drawing of a crocodile with a pencil encourages you to write, how fun!
texts.sectioneli5-22-0: A 'biome' is like a big neighborhood where there are many types of climates, and where plants and animals live together. It is a large natural area like a jungle or a desert. By completing the words, we will learn more about what makes each biome special, like the plants and animals that live there. Think about which words fit to better understand these natural areas!
texts.sectioneli5-22-1: Let's explain some words. When we talk about 'deciduous foliage', it means that the leaves of trees and shrubs fall during the cold weather. 'Predators' are animals that hunt other animals to live. And when we talk about 'oilseeds', they are plants that can be used to make oil, such as sunflowers or soybeans.
texts.sectioneli5-23-0: People live in natural places called biomes. To get what they need, such as food or houses, they change these places. This can be good or bad for nature. For example, building structures or planting crops modifies the environment. It is important to understand that all parts of the Earth have been changed in some way by people. Therefore, we must learn to take care of the environment while we live in it.
texts.sectioneli5-23-1: Let's talk about how some of the things we do can harm our planet. One of these things is deforestation, which is when we cut down many trees. This can cause two big problems: soil loss, which means that the land becomes bad for planting, and the loss of biodiversity, which means that some plants and animals can disappear. It is important to know these consequences to better care for the Earth.
texts.sectioneli5-24-0:
Let's talk about two places called biomes: the savanna and the desert.

- In the savanna, the climate is tropical. There is a rainy season and a dry one. Animals such as the jaguar and the deer live there. People there engage in agriculture and take care of animals like cows.

- In the desert, there is very little water, it is very hot, and the temperature can change. There are special plants called xerophytes, such as cacti, that live with little water. People also look for minerals here.

Cacti are xerophytic plants; this means they can live with very little water.
texts.sectioneli5-24-1:
Biomes are like big houses for many animals and plants. In America, there are two interesting biomes: the savanna and the desert.

The **savanna** is like a warm place with two types of climate: one dry and one rainy. Animals like jaguars and deer live here. In the savanna, people practice agriculture and raise animals.

On the other hand, the **desert** is very dry and hot. Desert plants, called **xerophytes**, are special plants that can live without much water, like cacti. In the desert, valuable things in the ground, like minerals, are sought. It's amazing how nature has its tricks to survive!
texts.sectioneli5-25-0: In this game, you must find which words go together because they have something in common. For example, "mountain" is related to "slope" because mountains have slopes. It's like matching socks: you look for the ones that make a good team together. Ask why some words like "trees" are related to "forests" and discover the correct pairs. It's a fun way to learn how things in nature are connected!
texts.sectioneli5-25-1: In this game, we look for a word that has something in common with two given words. For example, if you have 'liquid' and 'gaseous', think about what else it could be, like 'state of water'. This is like finding the piece that connects two parts of a puzzle. In this way, we learn how words can be connected.
texts.sectioneli5-26-0: Wangari Maathai was a biologist from Kenya who wanted to help her country by planting trees. She thought that planting trees could improve people's lives and also take care of the environment. Her project was called Green Belt, and together with many other people, they planted millions of trees in Africa. For her great work, she was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize! In the photo, you can see what she looked like.
texts.sectioneli5-26-1: Chico Mendes was a person who worked collecting rubber in Brazil. He wanted to take care of the forest because some people were cutting down too many trees without considering the damage. So he spoke with many people to stop them and protect nature. Although he was very brave, some people did not want him to speak, but his effort helped many other people around the world realize the importance of caring for the environment.
texts.sectioneli5-26-2: Jacques-Yves Cousteau was an explorer who loved the ocean and wanted to take care of it. He traveled the world filming videos underwater to show everyone the animals and plants that live in the sea. He also organized large efforts to prevent people from throwing dangerous trash into the water. Thanks to his work and the help of many people, he managed to keep the sea clean on several occasions.
texts.sectioneli5-26-3: In the Arctic, which is a very cold part of the world, people called Inuit live. They know a lot about the animals and plants there because they live in that place. There is a woman named Caroline Cannon who is from there. She works very hard alongside scientists to take care of the Arctic because there are some companies that want to do things that could harm it. So she tries to protect her home and the environment, like a superhero of nature.
texts.sectioneli5-27-0:
This page teaches us to think about the words we use. Look at the poster about Arbor Day. It says that planting trees is important because they help us breathe. The phrase 'you are the air that I breathe' is a catchy slogan that makes us think about protecting trees and their benefits. A slogan is like a reminder that is easy to remember and gives us an important message. Planting a tree is being part of the solution!

This is how we learn about words, like verbs that say what we do, and pronouns which are small words like 'you' and 'I' that we use to talk about people.
texts.sectioneli5-27-1:
We have a poster that talks about how important trees are. Each part of the poster has a special function:

1. One part tells you how trees help the environment.
2. Another part invites you to help by planting a tree.
3. One part tells you who is conducting the campaign.
4. Finally, there is a short and catchy slogan that makes you think about taking care of trees, like 'You are the air I breathe.'

It's like a game to learn what each part of the poster does.
texts.sectioneli5-27-2: A slogan is like a short and easy-to-remember sign. It is used to remind us of something important. For example, the slogan 'You are the air that I breathe' wants us to think about the importance of planting trees, because trees help us have clean air to breathe. Thus, slogans remind us to do good things for the planet.
texts.sectioneli5-28-0: This activity is about how we use verbs with different personal pronouns. For example, we say 'I do' when we talk about ourselves. On this sheet, you see examples where you have to put the correct verb with words like 'I', 'HE', or 'WE'. This helps to learn how to use verbs correctly in sentences.
texts.sectioneli5-28-1:
Let's complete a short story using the correct words. The words we use to say who does something, like I, you, he, we, you all, and they, are called pronouns. These change how the action or the verb is written.

For example, if we say 'I take charge', 'I' is the pronoun that performs the action of taking charge. Look at the images: everyone is working together, and each character says something that helps complete the story.

Thus, you can use the correct pronouns for the characters to do things like bring water or help. It's like completing a puzzle with words!
texts.sectioneli5-28-2:
When we speak, we use special words called personal pronouns to talk about ourselves or other people. If I speak about myself alone, I use 'I', but if I speak about myself and my friends, I use 'we'.

If I speak to one person, I say 'you'. But if I speak to more than one person, I use 'you'.

When I talk about other people, I say 'he' for a boy or 'she' for a girl. And if I talk about more than one person, I use 'they'. That's how we say who's in the conversation!
texts.sectioneli5-28-3: In this exercise, we have to look for the forms of certain verbs that change when we talk about different people. Verbs in the infinitive like 'respirar' or 'sumar' are not changed. When we conjugate them, for example, the verb 'sumar' can become 'sumo' or 'sumamos' depending on who is doing it. Here we look for how these verbs change in the poster's table. This helps to understand how to use verbs correctly when speaking or writing in Spanish.
texts.sectioneli5-28-4: Here's a little word game. We want to find three more verbs and say what they are called when they are not changed, in their "infinitive form". For example, the verb "generan" comes from the infinitive "generar". So we are looking for other verbs like this. The image of the crocodile is a friend that helps us have fun while we learn.
texts.sectioneli5-29-0: When we see words like 'plant a tree' or 'be part of the solution', they are using verbs that tell you to do something, like planting a tree to help the environment. The images with little trees and friendly characters encourage us to participate and care for the world. It's like an invitation to do good things together!
texts.sectioneli5-29-1: When we tell someone what they need to do, we use verbs in the imperative mood. It's like giving gentle commands, like 'plant a tree' or 'take care of the plant'. The images show how to plant a tree, using these commands: prepare the soil, make a hole, place the tree, etc. It is a step-by-step guide to help the plant grow happily.
texts.sectioneli5-29-2:
Here is a guide to planting a tree using simple instructions. Imagine you are telling someone what to do in each step: 1. Loosen the soil in a square space. 2. Dig a hole in the center and place the roots of the tree. 3. Hold the tree by the bottom and place it carefully. 4. Make sure the tree is well planted and cover it with soil. 5. Arrange the soil around the tree with your hands. 6. If the soil lacks nutrients, add fertilizer. 7. Finally, protect the tree from animals that may harm it. 

We use action words, such as "loosen" and "take care", to clearly indicate what needs to be done.
texts.sectioneli5-30-0:
Think of the crossword as a word game where you fit the answers in the correct place using clues. Here I explain the clues:

1. It's like a big book of nature that tells us everything about animals and plants.
2. Imagine the little bugs that live only in droplets of water and you see them with a microscope.
3. It's like the "juice" that is extracted from plants to make things work, like gasoline.
4. Think of different places in the world, like a desert or a jungle, where different plants grow.
5. It's a story not about a place, but about a person and all the things they did.
texts.sectioneli5-30-1: Words have common parts called 'compositional elements', such as 'bi-' and 'biblio-'. For example, 'biblioteca' (library) and 'bilingüe' (bilingual) have these parts. This helps to form new words. 'Bi-' means something double or two, and 'biblio-' is related to books. It is important to note these parts to better understand words and their spelling.
texts.sectioneli5-30-2: Here is a game where you have to match words with pictures. For example, if you see a girl greeting in two languages, the word would be 'bilingual'. A bus full of books is 'bookmobile'. On a bookshelf full of books, you would think of 'library'. A plane with two engines is 'twin-engine'. The plane in the drawing has two propellers, so it is twin-engine. It is fun to see how words and images connect.
texts.sectioneli5-30-3: In some words, there are pieces that are used to form new words. These pieces are 'bi-' and 'biblio-'. For example, 'biblio' plus 'graphy' makes 'bibliography', and 'bi-' plus 'monthly' makes 'bimonthly'. We always write these pieces with 'b', and they help create new meanings by combining them with other parts.
texts.sectioneli5-30-4:
Let's learn about parts of words called 'compositive elements'. 

1. **'bi-'** means "two" or "double". For example, in the word 'bimotor', 'bi-' indicates that there are two engines.

2. **'biblio-'** means "book". For example, in 'library', 'biblio-' refers to a place with many books.

These parts help form new words and are always written with the letter 'b'.
texts.sectioneli5-31-0:
Forests are super important for the planet. First, they do something called photosynthesis, which is like cooking their own food using sunlight, and at the same time, they give us fresh air to breathe. Moreover, forests are the home or "habitat" of many animals, like deer and birds.

They also help prevent the soil from getting worn out or "eroded". That is, the roots of the trees keep the soil in place and prevent it from being carried away by wind or water.

When it rains, forests act like large sponges that absorb water and redistribute it, ensuring that there is not too much water running all at once.

Finally, forests store water, which helps during dry times when it doesn't rain much. All of this shows why forests are so crucial for keeping the Earth happy and healthy.
texts.sectioneli5-31-1: Forests are like large natural houses for many plants and animals. They also do something magical called photosynthesis. Imagine that trees have 'superpowers' that they use sunlight to convert air into energy and, while doing so, they release oxygen into the air. This oxygen is what we all need to breathe.
texts.sectioneli5-31-2: Forests act like a big hug for the earth. Without trees, rain and wind can wash away the soil, dragging it into rivers and streams. This can cause floods and landslides. But trees and plants, with their roots, hold the soil firmly in place so it doesn't get carried away. It's as if the roots were strong hands that keep the soil in place, preventing big problems and helping the soil to be safe and stable.
texts.sectioneli5-31-3: In forests, the tree canopies act like umbrellas for the rain. They catch the water and let it fall slowly through their branches and leaves. This helps to ensure that the soil underneath doesn't get too wet too quickly, so it doesn't take the soil with it or cause floods. In this way, forests protect the soil and prevent big problems with water.
texts.sectioneli5-31-4: Forests are like a large sponge. They capture water from fog and rain using the leaves of the trees. Then, the water moves through the roots and soil, storing it. In this way, forests can keep the soil moist even when it doesn't rain much. This is very important so that plants and animals can live well, even in times of drought.
texts.sectioneli5-32-0: Before writing a summary, you need to understand the text well. First, re-read the article about the functions of forests. You have to see how each part of the text connects with important words in a list, such as photosynthesis or habitat. You have to write the paragraph number that goes with each word and fill out a table to show these relationships. This will help you understand and summarize the text better.
texts.sectioneli5-32-1: Here we are learning about what forests do. Each important word, like 'photosynthesis' or 'water storage', tells us a task that forests do to help the Earth. For example, the tree canopies help to take care of the soil because they catch and spread the rain. This is important to understand how forests protect and sustain the environment.
texts.sectioneli5-33-0: Imagine that forests are like great friends of nature. First, the wind and rain cannot remove so much soil because the roots of the trees keep it in place, as if they were hugging it tightly. Also, many animals can live happily because the forest is their home. Furthermore, trees help us breathe better because they produce oxygen, which is what we need to breathe. Therefore, forests are very important because they do all this for us and the animals.
texts.sectioneli5-33-1: Forests are super important and rich places in life. They have many plants and animals living in them. When you write about them, you can use words that help link ideas, like 'additionally' or 'finally'. This way, you can explain why forests are so special.
texts.sectioneli5-34-0: Study manuals are books that help you understand what you learn in school. They are like dictionaries, providing reliable information. They make difficult topics easy. They have texts, drawings, maps, and fun activities to learn better. Everything is clearly organized so that students understand it well.
texts.sectioneli5-35-0: In large cities, there are environmental problems that people face every day. One of these problems is that it is getting hotter. The activity invites making a list of these problems to better understand how they affect daily life.
texts.sectioneli5-35-1: Large cities have several problems because there are many people living in a small space. First, the air can become very dirty due to gases from cars and factories. This dirty air, called smog, makes us sick and makes it hotter. Also, the noise from traffic bothers us. Additionally, there are many cars and sometimes they get stuck, causing traffic jams. Lastly, a lot of water, food, and energy is used, and a lot of garbage is produced that needs to be collected and cleaned. This can be complicated because cleaning systems are not always sufficient.
texts.sectioneli5-36-0: Trees in cities are very useful because they help in many ways. They provide protection from the sun and rain, and capture harmful things from the air, like dust and smoke. They also help increase the value of houses and block the wind. Trees clean the air, providing pure oxygen and are a home for animals. Additionally, they make the streets more beautiful, reduce noise, and lower the temperature. That's why trees make life better and more pleasant!
texts.sectioneli5-36-1: Planting trees in the city is very good for several reasons. Trees help make the air cleaner and the place cooler, which means it can be less hot. They also protect from the sun and rain and provide a home for many animals. Additionally, having trees makes the neighborhood look nicer and can increase the value of houses. Therefore, trees are not only beautiful but also very useful for solving problems like heat and pollution.
texts.sectioneli5-37-0: The activity asks you to write about how trees can help solve problems in cities, such as pollution. Cities grow and that is good because more people can go to school, get jobs, and take care of their health. But it also brings problems like dirty air. Trees can help clean the air, so they are important for having a better and healthier city.
texts.sectioneli5-37-1: Cities have problems like dirty air and a lot of heat. Do you know how we can help solve this? With trees! Trees in the city clean the air, provide shade to keep things cooler, and make everything look nicer. They are important friends for our world.
texts.sectioneli5-37-2: Trees in the city are like little heroes that help solve problems. They reduce heat and clean the air, making the city a better place to live. So, even though cities have their problems, planting trees can greatly help make everything more beautiful and healthy.
texts.sectioneli5-38-0: You should review what you wrote about cities and environmental problems. Make sure that your text answers questions like if you talk about how pollution affects cities, how air affects people, and what happens with garbage. The idea is to make what you wrote clear and include all the important information. The image shows children reviewing their work, just as you should do with yours.
texts.sectioneli5-38-1: Here it is talking about how trees in the city can help improve the air. Trees are very important because they make the air cleaner and fresher. They also give us shade and a place to play. When writing about this, it is important to say how trees help and why they are good for us.
texts.sectioneli5-38-2:
When reviewing your writing, make sure to: 
- Start sentences with capital letters and use periods and commas correctly, just like putting shoes on your words so they walk properly.
- Avoid repeating words over and over. It's like saying "very big" instead of "huge."
- Use specific words. It's like using a magnifying glass to narrate things in detail, not like when you're talking to your friends.
- Connect the ideas. As if you were using glue to join sentences so that everything makes sense together with the subtitle.
texts.sectioneli5-39-0: A long time ago, when people were exploring America, they wrote about amazing things they saw. For example, one explorer said there were trees so huge they couldn't see their tops, and many men together could barely encircle the trunk. These stories were interesting, but sometimes a bit exaggerated compared to what we know today.
texts.sectioneli5-39-1: A long time ago, explorers told very strange stories about people in America. For example, they said there were men with three rows of teeth or feet so big that they used them as umbrellas. There were also drawings of different plants. All of this was not real, just the imaginations of people from that era!
texts.sectioneli5-39-2: When Christopher Columbus first arrived in America, he thought it was a wonderful place. He said that the sea was as calm as a river and the air was cool. He also talked about many colorful birds flying in the sky. At that time, people also imagined enormous creatures in the sea, like the drawing you see of a sea monster next to a ship.
texts.sectioneli5-39-3: A long time ago, some travelers told highly exaggerated stories about America. They spoke of things like giant trees or people with enormous feet. There are even drawings that show very strange things. Can we believe everything they said? Maybe not, because they saw the world in a different way and liked to tell incredible things. It's like when we play to imagine fantastic things!
texts.easyread-text-0-0: Notebook for fifth-grade children to read and write.
texts.easyread-text-0-1: Initial education is for young children and primary education is for older children.
texts.easyread-text-2-0: Notebook for learning to read and write in fifth grade.
texts.easyread-text-2-1: Initial and primary education means teaching young children in school.
texts.easyread-text-6-0: It is a list of where to find things in a book.
texts.easyread-text-6-4: Biomes are large areas with special nature, such as forests, deserts, and jungles.
texts.easyread-text-6-6: Forests are important. They provide a home for many animals and plants. They also help clean the air and give us oxygen to breathe.
texts.easyread-text-6-8: People can see problems in different ways. They can have different opinions and reasons.
texts.easyread-text-6-9: The 'anti-princesses' are story characters who are not like traditional princesses. They do not follow the same rules and show that girls can be different and strong.
texts.easyread-text-6-11: Equality between men and women is important for everyone.
texts.easyread-text-6-14: The tavern where the parrot is on someone's shoulder.
texts.easyread-text-6-16: The Brazilian warship called Solimoes had a disaster.
texts.easyread-text-7-0: I am Yacaré and I am a caiman.
texts.easyread-text-7-1: I will be with you while you read and write.
texts.easyread-text-7-2: If you see me with a pencil, come write with me.
texts.easyread-text-7-3: If you see me with a book, I will invite you to read.
texts.easyread-text-7-4: When you see me in a circle, come to listen to a reading.
texts.easyread-text-8-0: These are my friends: the Owl and the Jaguar.
texts.easyread-text-8-1: I am in the fourth-grade book.
texts.easyread-text-8-2: I will wait for you in sixth grade.
texts.easyread-text-8-3: The yacare caiman is an animal that lives in rivers and lakes. It has tough skin and sharp teeth. It eats fish and other small animals. The yacare caiman can grow very large and lives in South America.
texts.easyread-text-8-4: It is a type of crocodile from the alligator family.
texts.easyread-text-8-5: This animal is called the yacaré overo. Its scientific name is Caiman latirostris.
texts.easyread-text-8-6: It can measure more than three meters.
texts.easyread-text-8-7: It makes its nest in a quiet lagoon.
texts.easyread-text-8-8: Makes a pile with things found nearby.
texts.easyread-text-8-9: The nest can be very large, about 1 meter wide and 60 centimeters high.
texts.easyread-text-8-10: Mothers take care of their babies alone and protect them from dangerous animals, like large birds.
texts.easyread-text-8-11: This animal only eats meat. It eats snails, mollusks, and crabs.
texts.easyread-text-8-12: It catches reptiles and small animals, like rats, mice, and bats.

Biomes are places on Earth where animals and plants live. There are different types of biomes like forests, deserts, and oceans.
